Ru so over the last few years most of us have become familiar with this picture

three years ago with a very large Hado cluster to store all our customer data
uh uh sometimes it would be multi-tenant and in some cases it was not
multi-tenant and we would store for our bigger customers everything in their own
private Haro cluster this was running on Amazon web services as a very large set
of ec2 instances as we uh uh kept our
applications Life as we kept executing this data workflow in uh in Amazon web
services we noticed couple of important things with this
cluster the first observation we found was that the cluster was overwhelmed for
small periods so every day between let's say uh 12: noon and 2:00 p.m. the
cluster would become almost unresponsive because there were so many
requests running on this cluster for those two hours but more
importantly what we noticed was that the cluster light unused for many hours in
the day so sometimes in some clusters we noticed that for 22 hours a day the
cluster just uh uh lay unused very few jobs were running very few operations
were running and yet uh we had this cluster up and uh we couldn't do
anything about it because uh whenever we needed it we needed the maximum
Firepower that the giant cluster could give us so we decided to work with
Amazon and and figure out a solution for this so the first step that we did was
was we identified all the independent data sources so for example in the case
of Ticket Master we identified that concerts ports and events are distinct
data sources if they are distinct then why put them on a single giant
cluster so we created Amazon ec2 instances for data source so of course
this would mean that we would have around 100 distinct clusters running on
Amazon web services now this allowed us to run
these data flows independently so for those two hours when there's a lot of jobs running they
don't run into each other so if uh you're running a Hadoop map reduce workflow for concerts and at the same
time you're running something for sports they don't uh compete for the resources
because they are running on different clusters so that was our first solution
that we don't have the cluster getting uh completely overwhelmed during High
usage periods but what does that mean suddenly we had given 100 uh data sources we had
up to 100 independent clusters now any of us who have uh
worked with actual data centers and actual clusters will notice that as soon
as you have clusters you have to administer them you have to add new nodes you have to uh uh uh remove some

uh every uh every few hours even though technology has has
become better and better data centers are becoming more more and more sophisticated we found that we would
still need operations Engineers to monitor these
clusters as soon as we had to add operations Engineers the cost of
maintaining these clusters started going up not because we had we had high bills
from our data center but simply because somebody had to monitor these clusters
for performance perance for scaling and for failures now that we had this problem
again we went back to Amazon web services and we worked with them to figure out if there is a service that

was the Amazon ec2 uh elastic map reduce service map matched our use case we
wanted a large number of uh uh Hado computing power for short periods of
time every uh uh every morning so uh what we did was we took
all our different data sources took them apart we made them Amazon elastic map
reduce uh uh uh clusters what this meant was that these clusters would come up
for a couple of hours in the morning so let's say concerts would data would
be available at 8:00 a.m. in the morning around 8:15 an Amazon uh uh elastic map
reduce cluster would come up and it would perform the 20 or 30 ETL steps uh

found was uh we were able to uh uh run this at a much lower cost our operations
engineer did not have to uh uh worry about the the uh size of the cluster

50 noes instead of 40 noes with this service we were able to

Engineers to be able to uh uh to to be able to dynamically provision uh
computing power for
hadu but we found an important issue once we move to this
architecture if you notice in this in this uh picture we have four different
clusters talking to S3 or Amazon RDS so the first cluster is pushing data
the second cluster third cluster are all pushing data into Amazon
S3 and on the application side another Amazon ec2 cluster is pulling that data
so that it can be available to the to the end user of our
applications the problem with this scenario is sometimes a particular
cluster could become a bottleneck so an Amazon ec2 elastic map
reduce Service uh uh job is running slow and that is causing the entire workflow
to get stuck so even though we solved most of the scaling problems the fact
that one of the Clusters can slow us down was a very big
problem and rerunning these uh uh jobs on a new cluster would of course mean
that our operations engineer would be would be still kept busy which would mean that our cost of maintaining these
jobs is still high so how did we solve this problem market share has invented its uh
a patent pending technology called pause and play where we obsessively collect
statistics for each job so each of our stages we collect stats like runtime uh
cluster size uh uh uh historical time rate of data growth etc etc
given that we collect all these job stats we are able to predict how much time should this job take because we've
been running some workflows for over 300 days we're able to say that a concert uh
uh data workflow should finish in 10 minutes from 8:00 a.m. to 81 a.m. in the
morning if it doesn't finish within 10 minutes we are able to uh uh uh restart
that job on a new cluster or we are able to check the problems in an existing
cluster because of this we are able to keep all our uh uh various jobs uh in
lock we are able to synchronize the results from one to the other and uh
continue to use uh uh four or five or 10 different clusters for a single
application so what are our lessons learned from from nearly four or five years of
operating our business on Amazon ec2 using all these
Services the first thing we've learned is an architect for for Amazon uh using
Amazon web services should always think of their environment as multicluster a
single big Hadoop cluster is not elastic the idea is is to write
configurable ETFs so that you can use multiple clusters to get the job
done if your clusters up for the entire month you should check on the
utilization if they are not being utilized 80% of the time then it is better to move to an elastic map reduce
infrastructure so that you bring up clusters only when they are
needed the second observation is that there are lot of intermediate results it
is better to store them inside a service like S3 or RDS rather than storing them
on a a Hadoop cluster because Hadoop clusters
generally take up uh uh uh a lot of space plus they also take up uh ec2
instances even though you might not be running any jobs on them another thing to uh keep in mind is
compression if you can use compression then the lowcost storage becomes even
cheaper lastly what we have found is as soon as you move to a multicluster
environment there are many failure points that could cause your application to get stuck it is very important to
build uh the ability to restart directly into your architecture
rather than doing it uh uh as an as an afterthought or doing it as a bandid so those are our lessons learned
